principle_description: Start with customer and work backwards
question: Tell me about a time when you had to make a decision that was right for the customer but difficult for your business. How did you handle it?
quote: Leaders start with the customer and work backwards. They work vigorously to earn and keep customer trust. Although leaders pay attention to competitors, they obsess over customers.

principle_description: Act on behalf of the entire company beyond just your own team
question: Describe a situation where you took ownership of a problem that wasn't directly your responsibility. What was the outcome?
quote: Leaders are owners. They think long term and don't sacrifice long-term value for short-term results. They act on behalf of the entire company, beyond just their own team. They never say 'that's not my job.'

principle_description: Look for new ideas and ways to simplify
question: Give me an example of when you took a complex process and made it simple. What was your approach?
quote: Leaders expect and require innovation and invention from their teams and always find ways to simplify. They are externally aware, look for new ideas from everywhere, and are not limited by 'not invented here.'

principle_description: Have strong business judgment and good instincts
question: Tell me about a time when you were wrong about something important. How did you handle it?
quote: Leaders are right a lot. They have strong judgment and good instincts. They seek diverse perspectives and work to disconfirm their beliefs.

principle_description: Never done learning and always seek to improve yourself
question: Describe a time when you realized you needed to learn something new to be effective in your role. How did you approach it?
quote: Leaders are never done learning and always seek to improve themselves. They are curious about new possibilities and act to explore them.

principle_description: Raise the performance bar with every hire and promotion
question: Tell me about a time when you had to make a difficult hiring decision. Walk me through your thought process.
quote: Leaders raise the performance bar with every hire and promotion. They recognize exceptional talent, and willingly move them throughout the organization. Leaders develop leaders and take seriously their role in coaching others.

principle_description: Have relentlessly high standards
question: Give me an example of when you pushed back on a deliverable because it didn't meet your standards. How did you handle the situation?
quote: Leaders have relentlessly high standards — many people may think these standards are unreasonably high. Leaders are continually raising the bar and drive their teams to deliver high quality products, services, and processes.

principle_description: Create and communicate bold direction that inspires results
question: Describe a time when you proposed an idea that others thought was too ambitious. How did you approach it?
quote: Thinking small is a self-fulfilling prophecy. Leaders create and communicate a bold direction that inspires results. They think differently and look around corners for ways to serve customers.

principle_description: Speed matters in business
question: Tell me about a time when you had to make a decision with incomplete information. How did you proceed?
quote: Speed matters in business. Many decisions and actions are reversible and do not need extensive study. We value calculated risk taking.

principle_description: Accomplish more with less
question: Give me an example of when you achieved significant results with limited resources. What was your approach?
quote: Accomplish more with less. Constraints breed resourcefulness, self-sufficiency, and invention. There are no extra points for growing headcount, budget size, or fixed expense.

principle_description: Listen attentively speak candidly and treat others respectfully
question: Describe a situation where you had to rebuild trust with a colleague or stakeholder. How did you approach it?
quote: Leaders listen attentively, speak candidly, and treat others respectfully. They are vocally self-critical, even when doing so is awkward or embarrassing.

principle_description: Operate at all levels and stay connected to details
question: Tell me about a time when you had to go deep into details to solve a problem. What did you discover?
quote: Leaders operate at all levels, stay connected to the details, audit frequently, and are skeptical when metrics and anecdote differ. No task is beneath them.

principle_description: Respectfully challenge decisions when you disagree
question: Give me an example of when you disagreed with your manager's decision. How did you handle it?
quote: Leaders are obligated to respectfully challenge decisions when they disagree, even when doing so is uncomfortable or exhausting. Leaders have conviction and are tenacious. They do not compromise for the sake of social cohesion. Once a decision is determined, they commit wholly.

principle_description: Focus on key inputs and deliver quality outcomes
question: Describe a time when you had to overcome significant obstacles to deliver results. What did you do?
quote: Leaders focus on the key inputs for their business and deliver them with the right quality and in a timely fashion. Despite setbacks, they rise to the occasion and never settle.

principle_name: Strive to be Earth's Best Employer
principle_description: Create a safer more diverse and more just work environment
question: Tell me about a time when you took action to improve the work environment for your team or colleagues.
quote: Leaders work every day to create a safer, more productive, higher performing, more diverse, and more just work environment. They lead with empathy, have fun at work, and make it easy for others to have fun. Leaders ask themselves: Are my fellow employees growing? Are they empowered? Are they ready for what's next?
source: Amazon Leadership Principles, Amazon Corporate Website, 2021

principle_name: Success and Scale Bring Broad Responsibility
principle_description: Act responsibly and think long term
question: Give me an example of when you had to balance short-term pressure with long-term responsibility. How did you approach it?
quote: We started in a garage, but we're not there anymore. We are big, we impact the world, and we are far from perfect. We must be humble and thoughtful about even the secondary effects of our actions. Our local communities, planet, and future generations need us to be better every day.
source: Amazon Leadership Principles, Amazon Corporate Website, 2021

principle_description: Everything else will follow
question: Give me an example of when you made a decision that prioritized user experience over business metrics. What was the result?
quote: Focus on the user and all else will follow.
source: Google's Official Ten Things We Know to Be True, about.google/philosophy/

principle_description: Speed is a competitive advantage
question: Describe a situation where you had to balance speed with quality. How did you make that trade-off?
quote: We know your time is valuable, so when you're seeking an answer on the web you want it right away–and we aim to please.
source: Google's Official Ten Things We Know to Be True, about.google/philosophy/

principle_description: Always strive for improvement
question: Give me an example of when you improved something that was already working well. What motivated you to do so?
quote: Great just isn't good enough. We see being great at something as a starting point, not an endpoint.
source: Google's Official Ten Things We Know to Be True, about.google/philosophy/

principle_description: Professional excellence with intellectual humility
question: Tell me about a time when you had to admit you were wrong and learn from someone else. How did it impact your approach?
quote: Attributes like enjoying fun, a certain dose of intellectual humility, a strong measure of conscientiousness, comfort with ambiguity, and evidence that you've taken some courageous or interesting paths in your life.

principle_description: Speed enables innovation and learning
question: Tell me about a time when you had to make a quick decision with limited information. How did you ensure you moved fast while minimizing risks?
quote: Moving fast enables us to build more things and learn faster.

principle_description: Prioritize work that creates meaningful change
question: Give me an example of when you had to choose between multiple projects. How did you decide which would have the greatest impact?
quote: We are moving from a world where computing power was scarce to a place where it now is almost limitless.

principle_description: Embrace challenges and learn from failures
question: Tell me about a time when you failed at something important. What did you learn and how did you apply it?
quote: Our ability to change our culture is the leading indicator of our future success.

principle_description: Treat everyone with dignity and value diverse perspectives
question: Tell me about a time when you had to work with someone whose perspective was very different from yours. How did you handle it?
quote: We value integrity, honesty, openness, personal excellence, constructive self-criticism, continual self-improvement, and mutual respect.

principle_description: Protect user privacy as a fundamental right
question: Give me an example of when you had to balance user experience with privacy concerns. How did you approach it?
quote: We at Apple believe that privacy is a fundamental human right.
source: Tim Cook, ICDPPC Conference, Brussels, October 24, 2018

principle_description: Make the complex simple and intuitive
question: Tell me about a time when you took a complex problem and found a simple solution. What was your approach?
quote: We believe that we're on the face of the Earth to make great products, and that's not changing. We're constantly focusing on innovating. We believe in the simple, not the complex.

principle_description: Make wise decisions despite ambiguity
question: Tell me about a time when you had to make a difficult decision with incomplete information. How did you approach it?
quote: Netflix values behaviors like judgment, communication, impact, curiosity, innovation, courage, passion, honesty, and selflessness in employees.

principle_description: Only hire and retain the highest performers
question: Give me an example of when you had to make a difficult decision about team composition. How did you handle it?
quote: We aim only to have the highest performers at Netflix, modeling ourselves on a professional sports team, not a family.

principle_description: Create lasting positive change for clients
question: Give me an example of when you helped a client achieve transformational results. What role did you play?
quote: To help our clients make distinctive, lasting, and substantial improvements in their performance and to build a great firm that attracts, develops, excites, and retains exceptional people.
source: McKinsey & Company Official Website, Purpose and Mission Statement

principle_description: Invest in continuous learning and growth
question: Tell me about a time when you sought feedback that was difficult to hear. How did you use it to improve?
quote: We are a values-driven organization working to meet the highest professional and ethical standards.
source: McKinsey & Company Official Website, About Us

principle_description: Build deep collaborative relationships
question: Give me an example of when you turned a difficult client relationship around. What did you do?
quote: Having a partnership culture rather than a corporate culture was an advantage... What I try to do is make it clear that we all have a responsibility to BCG first.
source: Rich Lesser, former BCG CEO, Wharton Knowledge interview

principle_description: Deliver measurable sustainable results
question: Tell me about a time when you had to measure and demonstrate the impact of your work. How did you approach it?
quote: Unlocking the potential of those who advance the world.

principle_description: Work as one team with shared ambition
question: Give me an example of when you embodied 'a Bainie never lets another Bainie fail.' What did you do?
quote: A Bainie never lets another Bainie fail.
source: Bain & Company Official Website, Culture and Values

principle_description: Achieve extraordinary results that last
question: Tell me about a time when you delivered results that exceeded expectations. What was your approach?
quote: Across 65 cities in 40 countries, we work alongside our clients as one team with a shared ambition to achieve extraordinary results, outperform the competition, and redefine industries.
source: Bain & Company Official Website, About Us
